pullRequest.body:
We add the functions `delabSubscript` and `delabSuperscript` in the `Mathlib.Tactic` namespace. These delaborators are triggered only if the entirety of the provided expression can be subscripted (respectively, superscripted).

The delaborators are not exhaustive, in that they will not successfully delaborate every expression that is valid in a subscript or superscript. We instead aim to make them overly conservative, so that any expression which is successfully delaborated must be subscriptable (or superscriptable).

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

This PR is intended to serve as a predecessor to #20719.

Open questions:
- How to handle dot notation, `pp.explicit`, etc.?
- Can the tests be implemented in a cleaner way?

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [eab471f975](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/23018/commits/eab471f975111c87f19cdaa7335c7b5a71dc6956)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ delabSubscript`
`+ delabSuperscript`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Could you replace these with a more realistic case where you actually delaborate into `subscript` notation, and the test show the result is the same as the input?

something like
```suggestion
@[app_delab check_subscript]
private def delabCheckSub : Delab := withOverApp 2 do
  let #[_, x] := ( getExpr).getAppArgs | failure
  let x_d  withAppArg <| delabSubscript
  `(check_expr($x_d:subscript))
```
with a suitable `macro`
Should this be using the "current" expression, rather than taking an unrelated expression as an argument?
I think you're correct here, I just didn't know it was possible to extract the current expression.
I would believe you were it not for the fact that you wrote `( getExpr)` below!

Let's pick something more obvious, like
```suggestion
local syntax:arg "subscripttest(" noWs subscript(term) noWs ")" : term
```
(deliberately no `_`, because I want to know what happens if you try to subscript a superscript or vice versa!)
I think I have implemented this change, but I haven't quite understood what you mean by trying to subscript a superscript (or how best to test that).

Could you add a few more test-cases here of things that _aren't_ supported; things like:
* `^` and `smul` operators
* Notation like `Finset.card` and `Nat.factorial`.

This was an insightful set of tests, and they revealed the following bug. You can run the failing tests by uncommenting the `TODO` section at the bottom of `MathlibTest/superscript.lean`.

```lean
private def card { : Sort u} := @id 
local prefix:arg "#" => card

variable (n : String)

-- This passes, but for the wrong reasons. 
-- We (incorrectly) ignore the `#` and instead check if "card" can be subscripted.
/-- info: check_subscript #n : Unit -/
#guard_msgs in #check check_subscript #n

-- This passes (which is a bug), because "card" is valid in a superscript (but `#` is not).
/-- info: test(#n) : Unit -/
#guard_msgs in #check check_superscript #n
```

In short, the function application branch currently only considers the name of the function and its arguments. It does not account for any notation that may stand in for this function.

I don't know how to fix this yet, but I suspect it is also closely related to how dot notation will need to be handled.
I think the logic needs to be "delaborate the expression and then check if it's subscriptable", not "look at the `Expr` and guess how it will elaborate".

I was just thinking the same thing.

Originally, I was hoping there might be a `setPPNotation` equivalent to `getPPNotation`, where we could ensure that anything delaborated downstream of `delabSubscript` did not use notations. This would have the added advantage that we could also `setPPFieldNotation false` and prevent dot notation from spoiling a valid subscriptable term. Unfortunately, this doesn't seem to be possible.

I agree that the best route for supporting function application seems to be delaborating first and then checking if the delaborated expression is valid in a subscript (superscript).

Do you know of any existing delaborators that do something similar?

> I was hoping there might be a setPPNotation equivalent to getPPNotation, where we could ensure that anything delaborated downstream of delabSubscript did not use notations.

Yes, this exists; it will be something like `withOptions`, and you'll have to set ``pp.notation`` to false. I don't think this is actually desirable though, printing without notation is probably not what you want!

> printing without notation is probably not what you want!

I'm curious to understand your reasoning here. I don't really know the implications of doing this, but assuming it's possible to alter `pp.notation` only "downstream" of `delabSubscript`, it still seems to me that this could be a good option. 

It's unlikely that much notation would be valid in a subscript, so (to me) the least surprising behavior would be to delaborate `x.len` as `len x` and `#s` as `card s`. The alternative seems to be failing to delaborate altogether, which I suppose could be better or worse depending on how other delaborators are using `delabSubscript`.

The question is whether it's better to have `fooNotation ` or `fooNoNotation n!`, and I think I'd claim that since superscripts are fairly non-ergonomic (eg, regex matches skip them), we should choose the latter given we have to make a choice.

That's a good point, thanks for elaborating! Would it be worthwhile to have a variant of `delabSubscript` that *does* turn off downstream notations? Maybe this is already possible with `withOptions`, but the idea would be to let the caller decide how hard we should try to subscript/superscript.

Regardless, I will have a look at the approach you suggested (delaborate and then decide if we can subscript). Although, I don't actually know how to do this, so it may take me a bit to get something working.
Using `withNaryArg` is not safe here unless `e` is always `getExpr`; so you should drop the `e` argument from this function.
Can you add a test for this? A good one is `id id 37`
Can you add a test for `check_subscript (check_subscript 1)` etc for mixes of sub and superscript?
If this isn't imported I think you can drop this test; the `^` one is sufficient, especially given your new implementation.
Can you abstract this to a single function that takes in a `Mapping`. so that it's shared between sub- and super- script?

pullRequest.title: feat: subscript and superscript delaborators

source.title: feat(AlgebraicTopology): delaborators for truncated simplicial notations
